ygData.subject: Re: Quick Note on Maintaining Diversity
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, I agree that it is a good idea to explore very different parametrizations and the traditional ~20% selectivity is an interesting place to do that.  On

Colin, I agree that it is a good idea to explore very different parametri=
zations and the traditional ~20% selectivity is an interesting place to do =
that.  On the other hand, while you point out that in nature we don't have =
such large turnover, another big difference in NE (and evolutionary algorit=
hms in general) compared to nature is that a large percentage of offspring =
in NE are generally hopelessly defective mutants (even taking miscarriages =
into account).  So you could argue that the tradition high selectivity goes=
 hand in hand with the high rate of defective mutations.

Still, it is poss=
ible that what appears "defective" is a stepping stone to something that is=
 useful, so perhaps keeping it may help theoretically.  Yet my intuition ab=
out this issue is fuzzy because the defective mutants are usually not so di=
fferent from their parents genetically.  Usually what is happening is that =
they had the misfortune of moving slightly off a local optimum in a particu=
larly dangerous direction.  In that view, they may not be that helpful beca=
use the probability of going to the next promising stepping stone/local opt=
imum from them is hardly different than the probability of getting there fr=
om their genetic siblings with higher fitness, since they are so closely re=
lated anyway.  Even if a high level of diversity allows some defective offs=
pring to drift far away from their parents over generations, because such d=
rift is not really a byproduct of fitness, you could have gotten equally fa=
r away faster just with a higher mutation rate, so it's a complicated issue=
.

In general I tend to think that some kinds of diversity is better than o=
thers.  In a sense, if you are unique yet have low fitness, it is worth thi=
nking about what justifies investment in your reproduction.  I would say th=
ere are three major possible justifications in the case of low fitness: (1)=
 If your ANN is topologically novel then it might hold out the promise of b=
etter performance if we gave it time to optimize.  (2) If your phenotypic b=
ehavior is novel, then your neural functionality might present new capabili=
ties that we should explore further.  (3) If your weights are radically dif=
ferent from any we've seen before, perhaps we should spend a little time wa=
ndering around your neck of the search space in case there is something int=
eresting there.  However, the one type of diversity that might not be so us=
eful is if you are genetically and structurally very similar to your parent=
s and your performance is very low (and not low in a unique way).  In that =
case, the argument for investing in your future is less convincing.

Of cou=
rse, empirical results speak for themselves, and healthy diversity is a mat=
ter of degree, but these considerations hopefully at least give some useful=
 perspective that could help give context to an investigation of why raisin=
g the cutoff to 80% might be helping in some cases.

ken


--- In neat@yaho=
ogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> Back in April I outl=
ined an idea for maintaining broad diversity
> within a population which I =
consider to be a generalisation on novelty
> search. I'm still working on t=
hat front in order to try and get some
> expeimental results to back up (or=
 refute) the idea. In the mean time
> though while working on a test proble=
m it occurred to me that there's
> a very easy change we perhaps should all=
 be making in our existing
> NEAT code, and that is to select genomes from =
a larger proportion of
> the population. Withn NEAT we tend to think of spe=
ciation with fitness
> sharing as the principle mechanism for maintaining d=
iversity, which it
> does do. But if at each generation we keep, say, the t=
op 20% of each
> species (elitism) and also select from that same 20% then =
we're giving
> up a futher source of diversity within each species. (20% is=
 the
> default in SharpNEAT but I think similar values are generally used i=
n
> most NEAT based work).
> 
> If we think about populations in the natura=
l world then they have a
> much lower turnover rate where some small propor=
tion die and are
> replaced each year. Of course if you pick a longer perio=
d of time the
> turnover rate per unit of time is higher, but the point is =
that there
> is a more continuous and slow 'turnover' in populations, and t=
his
> allows diverse set of genomes to create offspring over and over again=

> despite having relatively low fitness. It's a balance between faster
> a=
pproach to local optima (and potnetially gettign stuck) and takign a
> broa=
der slower approach taking in a broader region of the search
> space.
> 
> =
I still think there's additional merit in breaking the region down in
> sub=
-regions and balancing the diversity evenly, hence I will be
> pursuing tha=
t idea, but for now many of us can improve diversity in
> our searches by t=
weaking some config settings. I tried this with a
> deceptive task that req=
uired an ANN to both balance a pole but also to
> swing it up from a positi=
on where the pole is pointing straight down.
> It's quite tricky combining =
the fitness from these two seperate tasks
> and increasing the elitism and =
selection proportions substantially
> does seem to help in this instance (e=
.g. I tried 80%).
> 
> Colin.
>
